204. 
Which of following pressure measured 
between venous and arterial side when 
heart stopped? 
A-
MAP 
8-
Diastolic pressure 
C-
Mean Syste1nic Filling Pressure 
D-
Carotid pressure 
E-
Systolic Pressure 
Ans: 
C (Guyton) 
Explanation: 
Mean systemic filling pressure is the pressure 
measured everywhere in the systen1ic circulation 
after blood flow has been stopped by clnmping the 
large blood vessels at the heart, so the pressures in 
the 
systemic circulation 
can be 
1neusured 
independently from those in the pulmonary 
circulation. The mean systemic pressure, although 
almost impossible to n1easure in the living ani1nal, 
is the important pressure for determining venous 
return.

Mcdullary respiratory center located in reticular 
forrnation 
Oorsnl respiratory group: 
• 
It is prirnarily responsible for inspiration 
and generates the basic rh)1hn1 
for 
breathing 
• 
lnput to the dorsal respiratory group 
comes 
from 
the 
vagus 
and 
glossopharyngeal nerves. 
The vagus 
nerve relays infonnation from peripheral 
chemorcccplors and mechanoreccptors in 
the lung. The glossopharyngeal nerve 
relays 
infonnation 
from 
peripheral 
chemoreceptors 
• 
Output from the dorsal respiratory group 
travels, via the phrenic nerve, to the 
diaphragm. 
Ventral respiratory group 
• 
II is prin1arily responsible for expiration 
and not netive during normal. quiet 
breothing, \Yhen expiration is passive 
• 
lt is activated for example during exercise, 
when 
expiration becomes an 
active 
process. 
Apneustic center 
• 
is located in the lower pons. 
• 
It stimulates inspiration, producing a deep 
nnd prolonged inspiratory gasp (apneusis). 
Pncu,notnxic center 
• 
It is located in the upper pons. 
• 
lt inhibits inspiration and, therefore, 
regulates

volutne 
and

Insulin(Tyrosinc kinase) 
Insulin tlecrcases blood glucose concentration by the following mechanisms: 
1. It increases uptake of glucose into target cells 
2. It promotes formation of glycogen from glucose in muscle and liver, and simultaneously inhibits 
glycogenolysis. 
3. It decreases gluconeogenesis. 
✓ Insulin decrease blood fatty acid and ketoacid concentration 
✓ Insulin decease blood a111ino acid concentration 
✓ Immediate action of insulin - Entry of potassi111n into cells 
✓ lntcrn1cdiate action of insulin - protein synthesis 
✓ Late action of insulin - Lipogenesis 
✓ A cl ion of insulin at cellular level is - Entry of glucose into cells

~feta plasia

P53 is a tumor suppressor gene," hen it ii 
absent or mutated it may indicate: 
A. 
Cell survival 
B. 
Apoptosis 
C. 
Cell death 
D. 
Cell necrosis 
Ans: 
A 
Explanation: 
• 
P53 is tumor suppressor gene and normally 
cause apoptosis when it is absent or mutated 
so it lost its function hence no apoptosis or 
cell death and cell survival v.1ill occur.

Pulmonary embolism 
Obstruction of the pulmonary artery or its branches by foreign material (usually thrombus) that 
originated elsc,vherc.

After n1astecton1y for breast carcinoma 
female deyeloped 'l\1inging of scapula, 
'l\'hieh is due lo dan1age to 
A.xi\lary nerve damage 
Long thoracic nerve damage 
Radial nerve 
Spinal Accessory nerve 
Thorocodorsal nerve 
n (BD+Grey's Anatomy) 
Explanation: 
• 
Because the long thoracic nerve passes 
down the lateral thoracic wall on the 
external surface of the Serratous anterior 
muscle.just deep to skin and subcutaneous 
fascia, It is vulnerable to damage. Loss of 
function of this muscle causes the inferior 
angle of scapula to elevate from the 
thoracic wall. resulting in characteristic -
Winging of scapula 
• 
Trapczius - Spinal accessory nerve 
• 
Scrratous Anterior - Long thoracic nerve 
• 
Lattism usDorsi - Dorsal thoracic nerve 
• 
Deltoid - Axillary nerve

deviates toward side of lesion

•

labyrinthine righting reflex, is a reflex that 
corrects the orientation of rhe body when it 
is taken out of its nonnal upright position. 
It is initiated by the vestibular system, 
which detects that the body is not erect

(Guyto11, Ganong & FA) 
✓ Occur every 90 1nin (4-6 period occur in Night)

✓ l)irficuh lo orouse from Sleep 
✓ 80¾ in Prc1naturc infant, 50¾ in Mature Neonate and 25 % in old Adult

✓ Bein waves appear ( I 4-80Hz) - High Frequency and lov, Amplitude 
✓ Also Coiled Paradoxical Sleep because person can still be Asleep despite Marked Brain Activity . 
✓ Also Called Desynchronized Sleep Because there is lack of synchrony in firing of Neuron Despite 
Marked Drain Activity 
✓ Short term memory involve Synaptic changes 
✓ Long term memory Involve new protein Synthesis and gene activation or (Structural changes)

area leads to Anomic Aphasia

... area 44 and 45 + inferior frontal gyrus 
Wemicke aphasia - Sensory aphasia + fluent 
-r area 22+ superior temporal gyrus 
Global aphasia -
Both Wem.icke and broca 
aphasia+ arcuate fasciculus 
Anomic aphasia -
Mild fluent aphasia + 
failure of word retrieval + angular gyrus

Limbic System 
• 
✓ 
Axons ofhippoca1npaJ pyrainidal cells converge to form the fimbria and, finally, the fomix. The 
fornix projects mainly to the mammillary bodies in hypothalamus. The mammillary bodies projt((b 
the Mtcrior nucleus of the thalamus (main1nillothalamic tract). The anterior nuclei project to the 
cingulatc gyrus, and the cingulate gyrus projects to the entorhinal cortex (via the cingulum). The 
cntorhinal cortex projects to the hippocampus (via the perforant pathway).

the ability to acquire new information

Kluver-Bucy Syndrome 
✓ 
Klaver-Bucy syndrome results from bilateral lesions of the amygdala and hippocampus. 
These lesions result In: 
✓ 
Placidity -There is marked decrease in aggressive behavior 
✓ 
Psychic blindness--objects in the visual field are treated inappropriately 
d

A Young lady has aphasia, due lo lesion of

cause 
A-
B-
C-

996 
Global aphasia 
Anomic aphasia 
Brocas aphasia 
Wemicke aphasia 
Ans: B 
Explanation: 
• 
Broca aphasia - Motor aphasia+ Non-
Oucnt + area 44 and 45 + inferior frontal 
gyrus 
• Wernicke aphasia - Sensory aphasia+ 
Ouent Non sense speech+ area 22+ superior 
tcrnporal gyrus. In wemike aphasia Patient 
has Difficulty in comprehending spoken 
~ords and Unable to Read(Alexia) Or Write 
in understandable languagc(Agraphia) 
• Global aphasia - Both Wemicke and broca 
·aphasia + arcuate fasciculus 
• Anomic aphasia - Mild fluent aphasia + 
failure of word retrieval + angular gyrus

Prevention 
✓ J>rlm11ry - Prevent disease before it occur i.e. HPV vaccination. 
✓ Secondary - Early diagnose and treatment i.e. Pap smear. 
✓ Tertiary - Treatment to reduce complication i.e Chemotherapy. 
✓ Quaternary - Avoid unnecessary intervention to minimize incidental harm.

Positive predictive value - The chance that the patient has condition if the diagnoslic test is positive 
Negative predictive value - The chance that the patient does not has condition if the diagnostic test 
is negative. 
Menn - Sum of all value divided by total 
Median - Mid die nu1n in a group of numbers 
Mode - Most co,nmon repented value in data 
Attrition Bins - Rclotcd to follo\V up and Prognosis

Confidence Interval - Mean and Standard Error
